ai-mn18:1.2_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling amongst the Sakyas, near to Kapilavatthu, in Nigrodha’s Monastery.
ai-mn18:2.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
ai-mn18:2.2_0: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Great Wood,
ai-mn18:2.3_0: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood apple tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn18:3.1_0: Daṇḍapāṇi the Sakyan, while going for a walk,
ai-mn18:3.2_0: plunged deep into the Great Wood.
ai-mn18:3.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side,
ai-mn18:3.3_1: He bowed, stood to one side, and said to the Buddha,
ai-mn18:3.4_0: “What does the ascetic teach? What does he explain?”
ai-mn18:4.1_0: “Sir, my teaching is such that one does not conflict with anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans. And it is such that perceptions do not underlie the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without doubting, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state.
ai-mn18:4.2_0: That’s what I teach, and that’s what I explain.”
ai-mn18:5.1_0: When he had spoken, Daṇḍapāṇi shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and he departed leaning on his staff.
ai-mn18:6.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the Banyan Tree Monastery.
ai-mn18:6.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-mn18:6.3_0: “Mendicants, having dressed in the morning time, I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
ai-mn18:6.4_0: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Great Wood,
ai-mn18:6.5_0: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood apple tree for the day’s meditation.
ai-mn18:6.6_0: Daṇḍapāṇi the Sakyan, while going for a walk,
ai-mn18:6.7_0: plunged deep into it, and approached the monks there.
ai-mn18:6.8_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side,
ai-mn18:6.8_1: While standing on one side, monks, the Daṇḍa said this to me:
ai-mn18:6.9_0: ‘What does the ascetic teach? What does he explain?’
ai-mn18:6.10_0: When he said this, I said to them,
ai-mn18:6.11_0: ‘Sir, my teaching is such that one does not conflict with anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans. And it is such that perceptions do not underlie the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without doubting, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state.
ai-mn18:6.12_0: That’s what I teach, and that’s what I explain.’
ai-mn18:6.13_0: When he had spoken, Daṇḍapāṇi shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and he didn’t shave it.”
ai-mn18:6.14_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-mn18:7.1_0: “But sir, what is the teaching such that the Buddha does not conflict with anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans?
ai-mn18:7.2_0: And how is it that perceptions do not underlie the Buddha, the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without indecision, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state?”
ai-mn18:8.1_0: “Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:8.2_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, he should apply himself to over.
ai-mn18:8.3_0: just this is the end of the underlying tendencies to desire, repulsion, views, the end of the underlying tendencies, the end of quarrels, arguments, and the accusations, divisive speech, and lies. This is the end of taking up the rod and the sword, the end of quarrels, arguments, and fights, of accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
ai-mn18:8.4_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.”
ai-mn18:9.1_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn18:9.2_0: When he had spoken, the Holy One got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
ai-mn18:10.1_0: Soon after the Buddha left, those mendicants considered,
ai-mn18:10.2_0: “The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. ...
ai-mn18:10.3_0: ‘Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:10.4_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, he should apply himself to over.
ai-mn18:10.5_0: just this is the underlying tendencies.
ai-mn18:10.6_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’
ai-mn18:10.7_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha?”
ai-mn18:10.9_0: “This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-mn18:10.10_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-mn18:10.11_0: Let’s go to him, and we could go to him.
ai-mn18:10.11_1: approach him and ask him about this matter.”
ai-mn18:11.1_1: and after going, they exchanged greetings with him.
ai-mn18:11.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side.
ai-mn18:11.2_1: They told him what had happened, and said,
ai-mn18:11.3_0: “The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. ...
ai-mn18:11.4_0: ‘Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:11.5_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, he should apply himself to over.
ai-mn18:11.6_0: just this is the underlying tendencies.
ai-mn18:11.7_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’
ai-mn18:11.8_0: Soon after the Buddha had left, Reverend Kaccāna thought:
ai-mn18:11.9_0: The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.
ai-mn18:11.10_0: “Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:11.11_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, he should apply himself to over.
ai-mn18:11.12_0: just this is the underlying tendencies.
ai-mn18:11.13_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’
ai-mn18:11.14_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?
ai-mn18:11.15_0: We haven’t this occurred to us,
ai-mn18:11.16_0: ‘This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. This was how he explains in detail to explain the meaning in detail:
ai-mn18:11.17_0: Let’s go to him, and we could go to him.
ai-mn18:11.17_1: approach him and ask him about this matter.’
ai-mn18:12.1_0: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves.
ai-mn18:12.2_0: Such is the consequence for the venerables. Though you were face to face with the Buddha, you passed him by, imagining that you should ask me about this matter.
ai-mn18:12.3_0: For he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.
ai-mn18:12.4_0: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.
ai-mn18:12.5_0: You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-mn18:13.1_0: “Certainly he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is holiness. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.
ai-mn18:13.2_0: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.
ai-mn18:13.3_0: We should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.
ai-mn18:13.4_0: Still, Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-mn18:13.5_0: He is capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-mn18:13.6_0: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”
ai-mn18:14.1_0: “Well then, reverends, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-mn18:15.1_0: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-mn18:15.2_0: ‘Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:15.3_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, welcoming, or getting attached to in the source from which these arise ...
ai-mn18:15.4_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’ This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this passage for recitation.
ai-mn18:16.1_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. What you feel, you perceive. What you perceive, you think about. What you think about, you proliferate. What you proliferate about is the source from which a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions. This occurs with respect to sights known by the eye in the past, future, and present.
ai-mn18:16.2_0: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. ...
ai-mn18:16.3_0: Nose consciousness arises dependent on the nose and smells. ...
ai-mn18:16.4_0: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. ...
ai-mn18:16.5_0: Body consciousness arises dependent on the body and touches. ...
ai-mn18:16.6_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact. Contact is a condition for feeling. What you feel, you perceive. What you perceive, you think about. What you think about, you proliferate. What you proliferate about is the source from which a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions. This occurs with respect to thoughts known by the mind in the past, future, and present.
ai-mn18:17.1_0: When there is an eye, if there is what’s known as eye, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’.
ai-mn18:17.2_0: When there is what’s known as contact, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘feeling’.
ai-mn18:17.3_0: When there is what’s known as feeling, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’.
ai-mn18:17.4_0: When there is what’s known as perception, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘thought’.
ai-mn18:17.5_0: When there is what’s known as thought, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.
ai-mn18:17.8_0: When there’s an ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-mn18:17.10_0: mind, thoughts, and mind consciousness, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’. ...
ai-mn18:17.11_0: When there is what’s known as contact, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘feeling’.
ai-mn18:17.12_0: When there is what’s known as feeling, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’.
ai-mn18:17.13_0: When there is what’s known as perception, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘thought’.
ai-mn18:17.14_0: When there is what’s known as thought, it’s possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.
ai-mn18:18.1_0: When there is no eye, no sights, and no eye consciousness, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’.
ai-mn18:18.2_0: When there isn’t what’s known as contact, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘feeling’.
ai-mn18:18.3_0: When there isn’t what’s known as feeling, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’.
ai-mn18:18.4_0: When there isn’t what’s known as perception, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’.
ai-mn18:18.5_0: When there isn’t what’s known as thought, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.
ai-mn18:18.8_0: When there’s no ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-mn18:18.9_0: When there’s no body. When there’s no touches ...
ai-mn18:18.10_0: mind, no thoughts, and no mind consciousness, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘contact’. ...
ai-mn18:18.11_0: When there isn’t what’s known as contact, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘feeling’.
ai-mn18:18.12_0: When there isn’t what’s known as feeling, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’.
ai-mn18:18.13_0: When there isn’t what’s known as perception, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘perception’.
ai-mn18:18.14_0: When there isn’t what’s known as thought, it’s not possible to point out what’s known as ‘being beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions’.
ai-mn18:19.1_0: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of that brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-mn18:19.2_0: ‘When a mendicant is beset with respect to proliferation, they should look forward to enjoying identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.’ ...
ai-mn18:19.3_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’ This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this passage for recitation.
ai-mn18:19.4_0: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
ai-mn18:19.5_0: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-mn18:20.1_0: “Yes, reverend,” said those mendicants, approving and agreeing with what Mahākaccāna said.
ai-mn18:20.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-mn18:20.2_0: “Sir, the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-mn18:20.3_0: ‘Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:20.4_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, he should apply himself to over.
ai-mn18:20.5_0: just this is the underlying tendencies.
ai-mn18:20.6_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.’
ai-mn18:20.7_0: Soon after the Buddha had left, those mendicants thought:
ai-mn18:20.8_0: The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.
ai-mn18:20.9_0: “Mendicant, a person is beset by concepts of identity that emerge from the proliferation of perceptions.
ai-mn18:20.10_0: If they don’t find anything worth approving, he should apply himself to over.
ai-mn18:20.11_0: just this is the end of the underlying tendencies to desire, repulsion, views, the end of the underlying tendencies, the end of quarrels, arguments, and the accusations, divisive speech, and lies. This is the end of taking up the rod and the sword, the end of quarrels, arguments, and fights, of accusations, divisive speech, and lies.
ai-mn18:20.12_0: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.”
ai-mn18:20.13_0: Who can explain in detail the meaning of this brief summary given by the Buddha?’
ai-mn18:20.15_0: ‘This Venerable Mahākaccāna is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions. Then we can visit him in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation.
ai-mn18:20.15_1: approach him and ask him about this matter.’
ai-mn18:20.16_1: and after approaching he asked venerable Mahākaccāna about this matter.
ai-mn18:20.17_0: “Mahākaccāna clearly explained the meaning to us in this manner, with these words and phrases.”
ai-mn18:21.1_0: “Mendicants, Mahākaccāna is astute, he has great wisdom.
ai-mn18:21.2_0: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as Mahākaccāna.
ai-mn18:21.3_0: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”
ai-mn18:22.1_0: After this was said, venerable Ānanda addressed the Fortunate One, (saying):
ai-mn18:22.2_0: “Sir, suppose a person who was weak with hunger was to obtain a honey-cake. Wherever they taste it, they would enjoy a sweet, delicious flavor.
ai-mn18:22.3_0: In the same way, wherever a sincere, capable mendicant might examine with wisdom the meaning of this exposition of the teaching they would only gain joy and clarity.
ai-mn18:22.4_0: Sir, what is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”
ai-mn18:22.5_0: “Well, Ānanda, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Honey-Cake Discourse’.”
ai-mn18:22.6_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn18:22.7_0: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn18:22.8_0: The eighth sub-chapter on honey-balls is finished.
